title: Lodash no longer added to window obj on docs site
body:
Not sure whether this or lodash.github.io is the better place for this issue.

As of either 4.14.0 or 4.14.1, it looks like `_` is no longer added to the window object on the (old) [docs site](https://lodash.com/docs) (it's nice to have it there as a playground). I assume this is due to the recent exports changes. Was this intentional?

title: lodash with artillery problem: ._getLabel error
body:
I have an issue with latest version of lodash (v4.14.x) with artillery plguin (stress test).

The error is: **TypeError: child.schema._getLabel is not a function**

I resolved with a downgrade of the lodash version (^3.9.1) but this version will not have maintenance.

title: v4.14.0 caused 100% CPU on both Chrome & Firefox?
body:
Hi:

Yesterday the React Web App I had in the continuous integration system `npm install`-ed the latest version of lodash (v4.14.0 upgraded from v4.13.1) with the following library lineup. Then every tests started failing. 

After some investigation, it was found that both the Chrome (Version 52.0.2743.82 beta-m (64-bit) & Firefox browser (47.0.1) would **_not respond**_ when using the Web App. The process explorer shows that the **_browser had consumed 100% CPU with the increased memory footprint overtime_**.

Initially, I suspected there were other libraries might have caused the issue, since there were several library upgrades that had occurred between the builds. However, by reverting all the library upgrades, and test the Web App by reinstalling one library at the time, the leads were pointing to the lodash library. 

Several attempts were made to try enabling the profile runs on both browsers, but it did not work, since the browser itself was already unresponsive. Not sure if the information provided here are useful to help with troubleshooting, any suggestions for how to debug the issue on the busy browser would be wonderful too. Thanks!

```
"dependencies": {
    "d3": "3.5.17",
    "deep-equal": "1.0.1",
    "intl": "1.2.4",
    "isomorphic-fetch": "2.2.1",
    "lodash": "4.14.0",
    "material-ui": "0.15.2",
    "object-assign": "4.1.0",
    "radium": "0.18.1",
    "react": "15.2.1",
    "react-addons-shallow-compare": "15.2.1",
    "react-bootstrap": "0.30.0",
    "react-dom": "15.2.1",
    "react-intl": "2.1.3",
    "react-motion": "0.4.4",
    "react-redux": "4.4.5",
    "react-router": "2.6.0",
    "react-split-pane": "0.1.43",
    "react-tap-event-plugin": "1.0.0",
    "react-vendor-prefix": "0.0.1",
    "react-waypoint": "3.1.0",
    "redux": "3.5.2",
    "redux-logger": "2.6.1",
    "redux-thunk": "2.1.0",
    "shallowequal": "0.2.2",
    "velocity-react": "1.1.5",
    "warning": "3.0.0"
  }
```

title: Cannot access original function attributes after wrapped by _.bind (__bindData__ vs metaMap)
body:
Current 4.x version of lodash `_.bind` does not use `__bindData__` variable anymore. 
Private `metaMap` weakmap is used instead. 
Client's code have no way to access original function. 

While this is valid and useful scenario for my case
For instance, we use decorators/marking functions to flag functions which do not require authentication. Then the functions are bound by lodash `_.bind`.

In older lodash our routing code could check that flag: 
`var flag = wrapped.__bindData__[0].flag`

In 4.x lodash we have no access at all to the original function and flags we set on the original function. 

Exposing `getData` private function to the public interface would restore required functionality.

title: `_.pickBy` and Symbol polyfill (core-js) do not play well together
As of 4.14.0, certain _.defautsDeep operations fail to detect circular references
body:
There seems to be a bug with 4.14.0 where certain (complex) circular references are not detected in _.defaultsDeep anymore. Instead, after a couple of seconds the process crashes and I get the following:

```
<--- Last few GCs --->

   95339 ms: Mark-sweep 1384.0 (1458.0) -> 1383.5 (1458.0) MB, 1291.6 / 0 ms [allocation failure] [GC in old space requested].
   96300 ms: Mark-sweep 1383.5 (1458.0) -> 1383.5 (1458.0) MB, 960.5 / 0 ms [allocation failure] [GC in old space requested].
   97388 ms: Mark-sweep 1383.5 (1458.0) -> 1383.5 (1458.0) MB, 1087.9 / 0 ms [last resort gc].
   98644 ms: Mark-sweep 1383.5 (1458.0) -> 1383.5 (1458.0) MB, 1256.0 / 0 ms [last resort gc].


<--- JS stacktrace --->

==== JS stack trace =========================================

Security context: 0x13ae381b4629 <JS Object>
    1: assignValue(aka assignValue) […/node_modules/lodash/lodash.js:~2247] [pc=0x105f210b33b0] (this=0x13ae381041b9 <undefined>,object=0x3139e681c879 <an Object with map 0x1035acf4899>,key=0x18560bfdb309 <String[9]: updatedAt>,value=0x3417b2026791 <an Object with map 0x7922ee5e831>)
    2: /* anonymous */(aka /* anonymous */) [...

FATAL ERROR: CALL_AND_RETRY_LAST Allocation failed - process out of memory
[1]    75312 abort      gulp test
```

I'm having problems to construct a minimal example, since it seems to be working with almost anything I can currently imagine. My best hint is currently that this worked with no problems up to `4.13`, so something must have changed.

The way this problem initially occurred for me was when using `_.deepDefaults` on https://github.com/sequelize/sequelize associations.

title: SQL-like queries over huge files with lodash
body:
I'm using lodash to write something like SQL requests to large log files: the main program writes various logs in the json format, then the file is read and parsed with `JSON.parse` and the result is fed to lodash. This gives me some insight into how the program performs. The approach is somewhat similar to collecting telemetry.

Here is an example of the logs file:

```
...
{ "a": 1, "b": 2 },
{ "a": 2, "b": 3 },
...
```

Here is an example of my lodash queries:

``` js
_(data)
  .filter(x => x.a > 0)
  .countBy("b")
  ...
```

The weak point in this approach is `JSON.parse` - it doesn't work well with > 1 GB files because it needs to have the entire file in memory. The solution looks simple: since the first query is usually a `filter` which picks a tiny subset of all the records, the json file can abstracted with an iterator. However it seems that lodash doesn't work with iterators:

``` js
> lodash = require("lodash"); lodash.VERSION
'4.14.0'
> G = function * () { yield * [1, 2, 3]; }
[Function]
> [...G()]
[ 1, 2, 3 ]
> lodash(G()).sum()
0
> lodash(G()).map(x => -x).value()
[]
```

It's also not clear to me how to implement a custom data source for lodash, to make it work with all these `map` and `filter` functions.

title: Injectable dependencies on Core build
body:
Hi, first of all, thanks for this great library =)

I'll use it on a large scale application and one thing I notice on setup step is that I have only 2 available builds in my case, the core or the entire library. 

The greatest things about lodash for me are the chainning pattern and lazy evaluation. If I choose the modular way by requiring functions or by requiring the Core bundle I will miss those features I just said...

I was wondering.. it would be great if I could have only the basic funcionality like this:

```
_( [ 1, 2, 3 ] ) // Do nothing...
```

``` js
import 'lodash/map' // Map injected
_([1, 2, 3])
.map( item => log( item ) )
.value() // [1, 2, 3]
```

``` js
import 'lodash/collection'
var youngest = _([
    { 'user': 'barney',  'age': 36 },
    { 'user': 'fred',    'age': 40 },
    { 'user': 'pebbles', 'age': 1 }
])
.sortBy('age')
.head()

console.log( youngest.value() )
```

Would it be better? Is it possible ?
This is not a issue, it is a enhancement instead.

title: Is _.pick not chainable in 4.14.0?
body:
`_([]).pick()` returns `Object {}`

If so, why there's not any word in changelog or API docs?

title: sinon useFakeTimers and lodash
isEqual and invalid dates
body: In the latest release, the behavior of `isEqual` on invalid dates has changed.  Previously: `isEqual(new Date(undefined), new Date(undefined)) === false` but now it is `true`.  This was a breaking change to the gulp test suite.

title: v4.14.0 broke _.noConflict()?
body: We had `^4.12.0` in an internal dependency's package.json, and we also have some legacy code that relies on underscore, so we've using `_noConflict()` to restore window._ to underscore. This was all working great until recently, when `_` became `undefined`. Seems like it happened concurrently with yesterday's `4.14.0` release? We've pegged our lodash version to `4.12.0` and that seems to have fixed it.

title: Document behavior of _.debounce when wait is 0
body: Clarify that when `leading` is false a debounced method with `wait=0` will not invoke immediately, but on the next tick (like `setTimeout`), but when `leading` is true the invocation will be immediate.

title: Fix missing semicolon
body:
I started on a documentation change but `npm run validate` after my initial pull revealed this linting error:

```
> jscs lodash.js

requireSemicolons: Missing semicolon after statement at lodash.js :
  5864 |    function isFlattenable(value) {
  5865 |      return isArray(value) || isArguments(value) ||
  5866 |        !!(spreadableSymbol && value && value[spreadableSymbol])
-----------------------------------------------------------------------^
  5867 |    }
  5868 |
```

title: Potential bug in unquoted paths with dots.
v4.14 doesn't compatible with Browserify
body:
Lodash doesn't work with Browserify after update to v4.14 because there aren't `global` variable unlike Node.js.

https://github.com/lodash/lodash/blob/master/dist/lodash.js#L364

``` js
/** Detect free variable `global` from Node.js. */
var freeGlobal = typeof global == 'object' && global && global.Object === Object && global;
```

**edit:**

The problem is that Lodash v4.14.0 can't read `global` variable when Browserify's options are set as `{insertGlobals: true, detectGlobals: false}`.

I think it should be fixed or documentated somewhere.

index.js

```
var lodash = require('lodash');
console.log(lodash.VERSION);
```

```
$ browserify index.js --insertGlobals true --detectGlobals false -o foo.js
```

node:

```
$ node foo.js
> 4.14.0
```

in browser:

```
> undefined
```

Add a `test` function for fp code

Test makes it easier to deal with regexes when writing code in the fp style.

Personally I have a function like this defined in my source `test = x => y => x.test(y)` (which can even be generalized further to a thing like `z => x => y => x[z](y)` but that's perhaps a bit obtuse), but it'd be great for this to live in lodash-fp.

title: Feature request: toRange(...) - Casts/maps a number from one range to another
body:
I searched the grounds here but couldn't find a similar request.

`toRange(...)` is for casting a number from one range to another. I've bumped into this method mainly while working with audio/music and 3D graphics, and I've found it very useful.

Proposed syntax is `toRange(number, fromLower, fromUpper, toLower, toUpper)`.

Here are some example uses:
- Casting periodic values to a positive range: `const height = _.toRange(Math.sin(x), -1, 1, 0, window.innerHeight)`
- Translate the mouse's position into a color parameter: `const hueShift = _.toRange(mouseX, 0, window.innerWidth, -10, 10)`
- Setting a boosting `GainNode`'s gain value from an `<input type="range" min="1" max="10" />`: `boostGain.value = _.toRange(input.value, input.min, input.max, 1, MAX_GAIN)`

I think it would be quite handy functional style:

``` js
import { toRange, mean } from 'lodash/fp'

const toWidth = toRange(0, window.innerWidth)
const sinToWidth = toWidth(-1, 1)
const numKeyToWidth = toWidth(48, 57)

const toReviewScore = toRange(1, 6)
const avgThumbsUpDownToScore = toReviewScore(-1, 1)
const movieScore = avgThumbsUpDownToScore(mean(thumbsUpDown))
```

Example implementations:
- http://stackoverflow.com/questions/10756313/javascript-jquery-map-a-range-of-numbers-to-another-range-of-numbers#23202637
- http://rosettacode.org/wiki/Map_range#JavaScript

I am unsure how nisched a problem this is, so it would be interesting to hear thoughts on this!

times(1, ()=> ''); // the result is [0]

times(1,  stubString); //the same result as above
times(2,  stubString); //the same result as above

What am I doing wrong?

title: When _.map with predicate String.fromCharCode getting a strange result
Feature suggestion: function to remove diacritics
body:
I suggest there should be a function that does a bit more than `_.deburr` - it should replace all non latin1 characters with their latin1 counterparts (ą -> a) and remove those that have no counterpart at all.

There are characters in latin1 other than supplementary characters which _.deburr handles, what may be required to be removed in certain use cases.

My use case: latin1 extended, diacritic characters in Polish language. I wish to reliably compare names on credit cards, which have no diacritics, and names defined by users, which may have diacritics.

I mean something between `_.deburr` as it is now and [FGRibreau/node-unidecode](https://github.com/FGRibreau/node-unidecode) which is an overkill, especially for front-end use cases.
#1430 may be related.

title: sortedIndexBy for reverse sorted strings?
body:
I've an array of reverse sorted strings `["AAZ", "AAY", "AAA"]`

How would I use sortedIndexBy to find the correct index?  It seems this function assumes a forward sorted array?   Currently I am calling `reverse`, then `sortedIndexBy`, `splice`, and then `reverse` again.

Some (incomplete) attempts at solving this with help of others on stackoverflow:
http://stackoverflow.com/questions/38448568/sortedindex-for-reverse-sorted-array/

title: Consider a _.equalIgnoringIndex function to do collection/set equality ignoring elements position
fp/debounce does not accept options argument
body:
I'm not sure what the behaviour should be here, but it's currently not possible to supply debounce with the `options` object in a functional way. [The FP Guide](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/wiki/FP-Guide) state it has a fixed arity of 2.

```
// does work
debounce(timeout)(function)

// does not work
debounce(timeout)(options)(function)
```

body:
You can see here that `zipObject` is not rearged:
https://github.com/lodash/lodash/blob/master/fp/_mapping.js#L360

`zipObjectDeep` should not either. Happy to do a PR if you'd like.

title: _.filter does not work with []
body:
After a painful debugging session, I've discovered that _.filter(arr, ['type', type]) fails where _.filter(arr, {'type: type}) succeeds.  I'm using 3.10.1.

```
var _ = require('lodash')
var arr = [{x:1, type:'abc'},{x:2, type:'abc'},{x:3, type:'def'},{x:4, type:'def'}]
console.log(_.filter(arr, ['type', 'abc']))
console.log(_.filter(arr, {'type': 'abc'}))
```

Output:

``` bash
$ node lodashtest.js
[]
[ { x: 1, type: 'abc' }, { x: 2, type: 'abc' } ]
```

So, either I'm misunderstanding the docs, or something is broken.

title: Clarify _.sumBy iterating behaviour when using arrays and objects
body:
The current `_.sumBy` behaviour with arrays and objects is not at all clear. I'm currently trying to fix up Lodash's type definitions for DefinitelyTyped, and I'm struggling to even work out what types are really valid, let alone how to use it.

After a little digging I think I've worked out how it works, so I've added details to iteratee explaining its behaviour generally, and a reference to that in `_.sumBy` explaining how that's used here.

I do think the array behaviour here (and probably everywhere that uses `_.iteratee`) is really kind of weird and surprising. For now, just documenting it seems best, but it might be worth considering future changes to that.

title: orderBy of columns with mixed types
body:
Hello guys! Can you tell how to use orderBy for objects with various field types. (strings and numbers)
For example
`_.orderBy([{a: 3}, {a: 2}, {a: 'a'}, {a: 1}, {a: 'c'}, {a: 'b'}], ['a'], ['asc'])`
I've got
`[{"a":2},{"a":3},{"a":"a"},{"a":1},{"a":"b"},{"a":"c"}]`
but how can I get something like
`[{"a":1},{"a":2},{"a":3},{"a":"a"},{"a":"b"},{"a":"c"}]`

title: Missing methods in typescript lodash
body:
> TypeScript code (from https://lodash.com/docs#chain):
> 
> var users = [
>     { 'user': 'barney',  'age': 36 },
>     { 'user': 'fred',    'age': 40 },
>     { 'user': 'pebbles', 'age': 1 }
> ];
> 
> var youngest = _.chain(users)
>     .sortBy('age')
>     .map(function(chr) {
>         return chr.user + ' is ' + chr.age;
>     })
>     .first()
>     .value();
> tsc compiler complaints:
> 
> error TS2339: Property 'sortBy' does not exist on type 'LoDashExplicitArrayWrapper<{ 'user': string; 'age': number; }>'.
> the same happens with pluck

https://github.com/DefinitelyTyped/DefinitelyTyped/issues/6586

Same happens with _.split and countless other methods.

title: Consider _.toggle function
body:
This is not the same request as #1677. Consider a simple utility function to toggle a value between one of two possible values. This would be useful to replace the following ternary statement.

`foo = foo === a ? b : a;`

`foo = _.toggle(foo, a, b);`

Thanks.

title: Lodash 4.13.1 "some" function does no work properly for plain array
wrong first call of customizer of _.isEqualWith
body:
Consider code

```
var a = [1, 2, 3]
var b = [1, 2, 3]
_.isEqualWith(a, b, (av, bv, i) => {
  console.log(av, bv, i)
  if ([+av, +bv].every(_.isFinite))
    return true
})
```

will output

```
[1, 2, 3] [1, 2, 3] undefined
1 1 0
2 2 1
3 3 2
```

so the first time `customizer` function is invoking not with _`objValue, othValue`_ as it says in the docs, but with _`object, other`_.

This is really a problem if `customizer` knows how to compare specific types of values but not arrays

title: Feature request: Inverted slice function
body:
I've got the case when I need to extract part of the string by a range of indexes and return the remaining part. There is a similar function [pull](https://lodash.com/docs#pull) but it works with array of indexes, not ranges.

Example:

``` javascript
_.slice('test', 1, 2); // -> 'tst'
_.slice('test', 2); // -> 'te'
```

Will be happy to implement this if it's suitable for lodash and receive enough votes.

title: _.foreach passing non-collection object
body:
Hi,

What happens when we pass neither object nor array to `_.forEach`?

It seems it does nothing, just returning the value passed and not executing iteratee.

Can it be used when we have undefined instead of array under a variable and just use `_.forEach` instead of doing explicit cast to array?

``` js
var x = undefined;
_.forEach(x, iteratee);
```

title: _.isUndefined() unexpected results
body:
when trying to use the lodash method of `_.isUndefined()` with a not yet defined `value` resolves with a `ReferenceError` of value not being defined.

Looking at the [source](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/blob/master/dist/lodash.core.js#L2925) for this method confirms why this error would be received. It seems this method was developed anticipating a declared AND 'defined' value (defined/undefined) before being passed into the method call.

``` js
function isUndefined(value) {
    return value === undefined;
}

/** 
 * Unit Test
 *
 * _.isUndefined(void 0) => true
 * _.isUndefined(null) => false
 * _.isUndefined(foo) => 'ReferenceError: foo is not defined(...)'
 */
```

Any reason not to utilize the vanilla javascript to check a values type instead?

Example:

``` js
function isUndefined(value) {
    return typeof value === 'undefined';
}

/** 
 * Unit Test
 *
 * _.isUndefined(void 0) => true
 * _.isUndefined(null) => false
 * _.isUndefined(foo) => true
 */
```

title: Add Support for non-native data structures using Iterables
body:
With the growing popularity of Immutable.js it's sad that lodash methods don't work with Iterables.

Would love if Lodash checks for iterables, and supports at least a subset of functionality on iterables.

title: _.isEqual for sets doesn't work in PhantomJS
Seperate rest into rest and baseRest
body:
Can `rest` be split into `rest` and `baseRest`. I want to avoid including all the `toInteger`  logic in asyncjs. Including `toInteger` ends up including:  `toFinite`, `toNumber`, `isSymbol`, `isFunction`, `isObject` and a bunch of primitives. This ends up being 1.26KB minified, 6.7 KB unminified.

I would be fine if this meant the start parameter was not optional for `baseRest`

title: _.is
body:
Hi,

Lodash has a lot of useful `_.is<something>` methods, although I sometimes need to create a predicate that will return true if argument is equal to my value. I can do it like this:

``` js
var is5 = _.partial(_.eq, 5);
```

But why not have an even more convenient method: `_.is`

``` js
var is5 = _.is(5);
```

And maybe if passing more values you can create an alternative:

``` js
var is1or2or3 = _.is(1, 2, 3);
```

title: npm is behind
body:
Don't know why but despite the npm branch at `4.14.0`, npm is stuck on `4.13.1`

https://www.npmjs.com/package/lodash

title: Query about pull request
body:
Firstly, sorry for making this an issue - it is more of a question but I wasn't sure where else to put it.  There are three questions:

1) I made a few potential additions: `_.intersperse` and `_.mapMaybe`, both based on the haskell functions of the same names:

``` javascript
function squareEven(v) { if (_.isEven(v)) return v * v; } // undefined (not falsy) return as "skip".
_.intersperse([0, 1, 2], 9) // => [0, 9, 1, 9, 2]
_.mapMaybe([0, 1, 2], squareEven) // => [0, 4]
```

I read the article on making issues to collect votes for feature requests.  Is it the same or a similar procedure for "unsolicited" new features with implementations and tests?  Do I just make a pull request, or first do something to gague desire for the feature?

2) I looked at making a pull request for these features, but that pull request seems to still include d30e41e, which was already integrated - I'm not sure why or how to stop it trying to resubmit that (I merged with the latest upstream version).

3) As the two new features are different, I put them in separate branches, with the intention to make them both separate pull requests.  However, this causes an issue with tests.  They both modify the `lodash methods` test module, increasing the number of expected "falsy" and "array return" tests by two.  Individually that is fine, but collectively that should be an increase of four.  Woudl it be better to combine them and submit all together?  Or do them very sequentially?

For reference, the changes I am talking about are here:

https://github.com/lodash/lodash/compare/master...Y-Less:Branch_intersperse?expand=1
https://github.com/lodash/lodash/compare/master...Y-Less:Branch_mapMaybe?expand=1

I tried twice to get a cleaner version of just my new changes on top of your upstream, but couldn't without just pulling a whole new one and manually inserting the changes.

title: _clone/_cloneDeep incorrectly clones arrays with deleted elements
body:
When cloning, values like length, properties should stay the same, which is not happening here.

``` js
var x  = ["a", "b", "c"];

delete x[2];

// cloned/deepCloned x should have these parameters identical as original x
console.log(x); // [ 'a', 'b',  ] this is strange but that's how JS works
console.log(x.length); // 3
console.log(Object.keys(x)); // [ '0', '1' ]

var xDeepCloned = _.cloneDeep(x);

console.log(xDeepCloned); // [ 'a', 'b', undefined ] FAIL
console.log(xDeepCloned.length); // 3 OK
console.log(Object.keys(xDeepCloned)); // [ '0', '1', '2' ] FAIL

var xCloned = _.clone(x);

console.log(xCloned); // [ 'a', 'b', undefined ] FAIL
console.log(xCloned.length); // 3 OK
console.log(Object.keys(xCloned)); // [ '0', '1', '2' ] FAIL
```

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Operators/delete#Deleting_array_elements

Please also handle both cases when non-last or last element of array was deleted.

title: _.keys shows deleted keys of array
body:
Was this intended?

``` javascript
var x = ["a", "b", "c"];

console.log(Object.keys(x)); // [ '0', '1', '2' ] OK
console.log(_.keys(x)); // [ '0', '1', '2' ] OK

delete x[1];

console.log(Object.keys(x)); // [ '0', '2' ] OK
console.log(_.keys(x));  // [ '0', '1', '2' ] what?
```

Even though this works correctly:

``` javascript
var y = {0: "a", 1: "b", 2: "c"};

delete y[1];

console.log(Object.keys(y)); // [ '0', '2' ] OK
console.log(_.keys(y)); // [ '0', '2' ] OK
```

title: How to use "bignumber" with "_.sumBy()"?
body:
I use `sumBy(.....)`, but the result show `123.219999999999999999........`.
So I would like to use with `BigNumber`.
Please help me.

title: cloneDeep() does not copy an Array root key/value property
body:
In a deep nested JSON, I am trying to cloneDeep() an object where there are some arrays of objects also present.

But my arrays also have root level key: value item present in addition to array items. Example:

Choices: [
selectedId : 34,
{object1},
{object2},
{object3},
...
]

On cloneDeep(), I do get all the original item cloned but not the root key/value - selectedId: 34
Manually doing this copies all the properties but not with lodash. Is this by design, I am using it incorrectly or a bug? I need the root properties in my arrays because I use the arrays also as objects in some cases.

Thanks!

title: Update uglify-js to version 2.7.0 🚀
body:
Hello lovely humans, [uglify-js](https://www.npmjs.com/package/uglify-js) just published its new version 2.7.0.
State Update :rocket:
Dependency uglify-js
New version 2.7.0
Type devDependency
This version is **not covered** by your **current version range**. Without accepting this pull request your project will work just like it did before. There might be a bunch of new features, fixes and perf improvements that the maintainers worked on for you though. I recommend you look into these changes and try to get onto the latest version of uglify-js. Given that you have a decent test suite, a passing build is a strong indicator that you can take advantage of these changes by merging the proposed change into your project. Otherwise this branch is a great starting point for you to work on the update. Do you have any ideas how I could improve these pull requests? Did I report anything you think isn’t right? Are you unsure about how things are supposed to work? There is a collection of [frequently asked questions](https://greenkeeper.io/faq.html) and while I’m just a bot, there is a group of people who are happy to teach me new things. [Let them know](https://github.com/greenkeeperio/greenkeeper/issues/new). Good luck with your project :sparkles: You rock! :palm_tree: --- The new version differs by 12 commits . - [`572b97b`](https://github.com/mishoo/UglifyJS2/commit/572b97b0bb48285497ffbffed9420468e1700956) v2.7.0 - [`698705a`](https://github.com/mishoo/UglifyJS2/commit/698705a820708ab2203869e1523b041030ad77cb) Don't convert all strings to directives from moz-ast - [`debc525`](https://github.com/mishoo/UglifyJS2/commit/debc525fa117438d4971df3790f9f476fed65858) Introduce a test that tests the --self build - [`5576e27`](https://github.com/mishoo/UglifyJS2/commit/5576e2737ad95c12d0a559015ff375c785232ec6) Document that the smallest sequences optimization length is 2 - [`b40d5de`](https://github.com/mishoo/UglifyJS2/commit/b40d5de69c61688dad8e9f5c1e99558e0e3bdc30) Change the default sequences limit to 200 to speed up compress. - [`b7ef784`](https://github.com/mishoo/UglifyJS2/commit/b7ef7840f3f0ab2bec09bec4d4b8a8bb8d50dc78) Allow sequences maximum length to be user configurable. - [`85924bb`](https://github.com/mishoo/UglifyJS2/commit/85924bb32e1c27f555aad1651f4575b45bcbadb1) Allow input files to be map (url->filename) - [`a97690f`](https://github.com/mishoo/UglifyJS2/commit/a97690fc724a7beba77d7fde449ea56676804933) Various LineTerminator changes - [`02c6382`](https://github.com/mishoo/UglifyJS2/commit/02c638209ee22816b1324ff0c0f47b27db1336af) Enable --screw-ie8 by default. - [`030611b`](https://github.com/mishoo/UglifyJS2/commit/030611b729af46d2239bd09c95f88e708660f254) Add Node API documentation for mangling options - [`335b72d`](https://github.com/mishoo/UglifyJS2/commit/335b72df03fb6593d4bac8ddcde7d1b128eb3c4e) Fix spidermonkey AST (ESTree) export and import, Array holes - [`3a7d53f`](https://github.com/mishoo/UglifyJS2/commit/3a7d53f3cfa81fc8df3cd61c9adf0ce6c28ecd30) Move OctalEscapeSequence to read_escape_char See the [full diff](https://github.com/mishoo/UglifyJS2/compare/9676167aac715d2dd10918e2beb13b1a4a372616...572b97b0bb48285497ffbffed9420468e1700956). --- This pull request was created by [greenkeeper.io](https://greenkeeper.io/). title: _.set function modify to accept an overwrite argument
Links to creation equivalents for in-place modification functions.
body: See issue #2467.  Basically, I just searched for every instance of "unlike", and added the opposite version.  If there are any other equivalent functions that were not previously documented in any way, they still aren't.

title: Documentation Request: Links for array mutation equivalent functions.
body:
The documentation for `_.remove` states:

> Note: Unlike `_.filter`, this method mutates array.

This is very handy, but the documentation for `_filter` has no equivalent statement.  If I know that I want the mutation version of a function, but don't know what it is, currently the only way I know to find it is to search for `_.filter` until I find a link like this back to it.  It would be very useful to have these equivalent functions linked both ways, including others like `_.without`/`_.pull`, `_.difference`/`_.pullAll` etc (I've not searched for a comprehensive list).

title: What about a nice lodash logo.?
body: I was looking at the lodash documentation which is very well maintained, the only thing that I found missing was a cool lodash logo on the site. Thought of giving this suggestion to the community.

title: Support 'filter' with 'fromIndex' option
body:
Hi,

It will be helpful if lodash support filter an array start from index like 'find' method.
Thanks

title: _.isEqual quirky circular case
With lodash/fp, _.truncate becomes _.trunc
body:
When I include the following scripts:

``` HTML
<script src="https://cdnjs.cloudflare.com/ajax/libs/lodash.js/4.5.1/lodash.min.js"></script>
<script src="https://cdnjs.cloudflare.com/ajax/libs/lodash-fp/0.10.4/lodash-fp.min.js"></script>
```

The function `_.truncate` is undefined, but `_.trunc` is defined and appears to do the same thing. I couldn't find any documentation for this anywhere. Is there a reason for this, and, if so, can it be documented somewhere?

Demo is [here](https://jsfiddle.net/ftan/afnt2jxk/).

Note that, in the fiddle, if you remove the script for `lodash-fp`, you'll get `_.truncate` defined and `_.trunc` undefined.

title: Add build script for doc site HTML files.
body:
To run, use the npm script like such:

```
npm run doc:sitehtml
```

The script will generate a file at `doc/v4.XX.YY.html` which can be copied and added to the doc site.

title: Document that _.any is an alias of _.some
Feature request: get all regex matches of a String
Weird behavior of the matchProperties syntax
body:
Weird behavior of the matchProperties syntax with this dataset

``` javascript
var a = [0,0,0,1], b = [0,0,1,0], c = [{path: a}, {path: b}];
console.log(_.findIndex(c, ['path', a])) // => 0
console.log(_.findIndex(c, ['path', b])) // => 0 (1 expected)
console.log(_.findIndex(c, (d) => d.path == b)) // => 1
```

title: Initial missing parameter for count
body:
Hi all,
in underscore there is the method initial which has an optional parameter **n** which makes it possible to remove the last n elements in an array. lodash currently does not have this parameter.

I think this would only make sense because initial without any parameter makes not so much sense to read. e.g.: `_.initial([2, 6, 3])` reads not as "everything but the last", however `_.chain(longArray).initial(5)` does IMHO read nicely as "the initial 5 elements"

title: Live & Interactive code snippets for lodash
body:
It would be very cool and very helpful to underscore.js beginners to add live and interactive code snippets to [lodash documentation](https://lodash.com/docs), with the klipse plugin.

Here is a demo of the klipse plugin: http://blog.klipse.tech/javascript/2016/06/20/blog-javascript.html

Disclaimer: I'm the klipse author.

title: _.isArrayLikeObject(value)
body:
From version : 4.13.1
This method is like `_.isArrayLike` except that it also checks if value is an object.

So, does this method suppose returns true for object or false? Because `_.isArrayLikeObject({});` returns `false`.

title: Fix reference to second param of _.invokeMap in doc description.
body:
Commit 0aef5155220ef4c6d7aad84cdfe441dd51b4265a changed the name of the second parameter of what is now `_.invokeMap` from `methodName` to `path`.

It is currently referred to as `path` on lines 8922 and 8932 of the docs, but on line 8924 it is still referred to as `methodName`.

This PR replaces the remaining use of `methodName` with `path`.

title: _.memoize causes v8 deopt
